perturbation.original_text: 6.5 Audits. SIGA may have an independent top four certified public accountant, reasonably acceptable to MMT (“SIGA’s Auditor”), have access during normal business hours, and upon [***] Business Days’ prior written notice, to examine only those records of MMT (and its Affiliates and sublicensees) as may be reasonably necessary to determine, with respect to any Calendar Year ending not more than [***] before SIGA’s request, the correctness or completeness of any report or payment made under this Agreement; provided, however, MMT shall not be required to provide, and neither SIGA nor SIGA’s Auditor shall be entitled to review, the tax returns or tax records of MMT or those of its Affiliates and sublicensees.
perturbation.changed_text: 6.5 Audits. SIGA may have an independent top four certified public accountant, reasonably acceptable to MMT (“SIGA’s Auditor”), have access at any time, and upon one (1) Business Days’ prior written notice, to examine all records of MMT (and its Affiliates and sublicensees) without any limits, to determine the correctness or completeness of any report or payment made under this Agreement; provided, however, MMT shall not be required to provide, and neither SIGA nor SIGA’s Auditor shall be entitled to review, the tax returns or tax records of MMT or those of its Affiliates and sublicensees.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the audit access terms to 'any time' and providing only 'one (1) Business Days’ prior written notice', coupled with 'examining all records of MMT (and its Affiliates and sublicensees) without any limits', creates an unreasonable and oppressive audit clause, likely violating the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing. Legally, audit clauses must be reasonable in scope and timing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing; principles of contract law regarding reasonable terms and conditions.

perturbation.changed_text: 10.1 Confidentiality. Each Party agrees that, during the Term and for a period of one (1) year thereafter, such Party and its Affiliates will keep confidential and will not publish or otherwise disclose and will not use for any purpose other than as provided for in this Agreement (which includes the exercise of any rights or the performance of any obligations hereunder) any Confidential Information furnished to it or its Affiliates by the other Party or its Affiliates pursuant to this Agreement, except to the extent expressly authorized by this Agreement or as otherwise agreed to in writing by the Parties; provided, however, that the confidentiality and non-use obligations imposed by this Agreement with respect to trade secrets included in an item of Confidential Information will continue for as long as the disclosing Party continues to treat such Confidential Information as a trade secret.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the confidentiality period to 'one (1) year' may be insufficient to protect sensitive business information, particularly trade secrets, potentially conflicting with industry standards and reasonable expectations. While trade secrets have perpetual protection, reducing the general confidentiality term to 1 year would make it virtually unenforceable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Principles of contract law regarding reasonable protection of confidential information; potential conflicts with trade secret law.
